Keywords: Soldier , Spy
Real Name: Sharon Carter
Special Powers
DEALING IN CONTRABAND: Once per game for all characters with this trait, at the beginning of the game you may choose an equipment equipped to an opposing character. If you do, that equipment gains UNEQUIP: DROP, is immediately unequipped, and roll a d6. That opponent places the equipment that many squares away from its current square.
KEEPING AN EYE OUT: Modify range +3, Ranged Combat Expert.
Figure Errata
Changed "DEALING IN CONTRABAND"
Trade Sharon Carter Want Sharon Carter

Comments
June 9, 2022
Bobcat2022
Why, thank you for asking, RavenProject! On appeal, my verdict is: eh. In the context where most-if-not-all equipment objects are Light, and can be carried by anyone, it’s not much-if-any more challenging for the opponent to pick up their dropped toy from 1d6 squares away than it is to pick it up from one square away. And of course, her trait only triggers once, at the beginning of the game. It doesn’t do anything for equipment that was always going to be manually gathered, which is where the really scary combos are; it doesn’t even affect characters that "start the game equipped" at points following the beginning of the game (e.g. Shifting Focus Wonder Woman). I’m comparing her to TMNT3028 Leonardo—a five-year-old SR next to a brand-new Rare feels pretty apples-to-apples—and thinking, wow, that space turtle holds up. Leo’s trait is a dice roll, but it triggers each time an opposing character would start the game equipped OR would become equipped. That’s at any point in the game, as long as he’s on the map, and repeatedly (not just the once-per-game that Sharon gives you). If your 2d6 is higher, boom, the equipment isn’t just dropped on the ground with a five-second rule, it’s removed from the game (and I think you’d score it, per 21.8 of the 5.19.2021 Comprehensive Rulebook). Plus Leo’s doing a lot more for you in combat than Sharon is. I’m also comparing her to the pieces from this set, like Tommy Maximoff and Heist Nebula, who can unequip opposing characters. Their abilities require a successful attack… but, y’know, you generally want to be going for those anyway. They also don’t give the equipment UNEQUIP: DROP like Sharon does, meaning you might just straight-up KO the object (all the Mandarin rings and most of the Wonder Woman objects, for example) and if it does wind up on the ground it’s in the thick of the fight, presumably on your turn, and you’ve got an actual chance to pick it up before your opponent grabs it back. Not saying she’s without uses, and not every piece needs to be for me. But for my 35 points she comes up short next to… well, a bunch of figures, but I’m looking at the 35-point CAAV006 Sharon Carter, particularly. I think that Common Sharon making a bigger SHIELD piece better is going to do more for me than this Rare Sharon striking out on her own.
June 8, 2022
RavenProject
Bobcat, I'd like to hear your revised opinion given her errata: "That opponent places the equipment that many squares away from its current square."
June 1, 2022
Bobcat2022
Apparently she comes with the Super-Soldier Serum item? That's not bad. Her trait's a little weak sauce, though, even if your opponent does start with an item equipped: "That opponent places the equipment up to that many squares away from its current square." Up to. So... one. One square away from the character that started with it. You're not going to get over to the dropped object before the opponent can pick it back up and/or equip it. Sharon's not "dealing in contraband," she's doing the why-did-you-bother combo of untying someone's shoe and then also saying "ha ha your shoe's untied." But she is a decent sniper if you've got a map with a square of hindering to drop her in. The Avengers Initiative folks in the Commons make her nervous, so deal with those first, I guess.
May 4, 2022
Goop
You can put her on a rooftop and get some snipes off maybe for 12/3. Still for 35pts there are better support pieces you can use.
